title: Wastewater Sequencing using the EasySeq™ RC-PCR SARS CoV-2 (Nimagen) V1.0
title_html: Wastewater Sequencing using the EasySeq™ RC-PCR SARS CoV-2 (Nimagen) V1.0

authors.name: Ronny  van Aerle
authors.affiliation: Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas), UK

protocol.title: Wastewater Sequencing using the EasySeq™ RC-PCR SARS CoV-2 (Nimagen) V1.0
protocol.title_html: Wastewater Sequencing using the EasySeq™ RC-PCR SARS CoV-2 (Nimagen) V1.0

source.description:
Aim: Reduction of any PCR inhibitors and potential concentration of RNA. Starting volume is 20 µl but this can be increased if further concentration is required (although for the latter tests on whether inhibitors are also concentrated have not been undertaken).
Notes: Use either AMPure RNA XP beads (Beckman Coulter Agencourt) or Mag-Bind® TotalPure NGS beads (Omega Bio-Tek), the latter being cheaper to use. Use aliquoted beads rather than directly from stock bottle to minimize risk of stock contamination. Ensure the aliquot is at room temperature and thoroughly mixed (vortexed) before use.

PCR Plates – Any style (skirted, non-skirted, full height, low profile), providing they fit the magnetic rack effectively.

Working environment – Ensure you work in a dust free environment, either a dust free bench or PCR cabinet. If you are in an area that may have a high risk for contamination, wipe down benches with household bleach (1 – 5%) prior to use.

Automation is possible, e.g. Opentrons (allowing at least 7 minutes on magnet).
Pipette 20 µl of RNA extracts into a 96 well PCR plate (plate 1).
Add 36 µl of Mag-Bind® Total Pure NGS beads (1.8X volume) and carefully pipette at least 6 times to mix.
Leave to stand at room temperature for 5 minutes.

If there is liquid on the side of the wells, cover the plate with a PCR adhesive seal and pulse spin down in a plate centrifuge (with swing out rotor).
Note: A plate centrifuge with a swing out rotor should be used to minimize contamination in case adhesive seals are not sealed properly.
Place on magnetic rack holder for at least 3 minutes to allow the beads to pellet. Note: the time taken for the pellets may vary between samples.

Remove the supernatant. This should be clear and without any beads if possible, although trace amounts of beads can be tolerated. If a large number of beads are taken up, replace the liquid back into the well, wait 20 seconds and then try again.
Add 80 µl of 80% ethanol v/v in MBG water to each well and leave to stand at room temperature for at least 30 seconds.
Remove the ethanol, being careful to avoid the pellets. Ideally remove a column (8 channel pipette) or row (12 channel pipette) at a time.
Repeat steps 2.7 to 2.8 once more.
Using a P10 or P20 multichannel pipette, remove any remaining ethanol from the bottom of each well.
Remove the plate from the magnetic rack.
Add 9 µl of MBG water to each pellet and carefully, but rapidly pipette mix/resuspend the pellet. Repeat this for the entire plate, changing tips between wells.
Allow to stand for 5 minutes at room temperature.
While standing, add 2 µl of LunaScript® RT SuperMix to each well of a new PCR plate on a chill block or ice (plate 2).
Optional - if there are air bubbles or residue on the side of the wells of plate 1, cover with a PCR seal and pulse centrifuge the plate.
Place plate back on the magnetic rack and allow the beads to pellet for at least 3 minutes.
Recover 8 µl of the supernatant and add directly into 2 µl of LunaScript® RT SuperMix previously put into plate 2 (Step 2.13), mixing gently 5 times with the pipette.
Cover plate 2 with a PCR adhesive seal, pulse spin down in a centrifuge and place the plate on a thermal cycler with heated lid.
Thermal cycler conditions: 25°C for 2 minutes, 55°C for 45 minutes, 95°C for 1 minute and hold at 4°C.
Use the EasySeq™ RC-PCR SARS CoV-2 (novel coronavirus) Whole Genome Sequencing kit from NimaGen using a modified version of the manufacturer’s protocol, as follows:

Thaw on ice:
• SARS CoV2 WGS Panel A probe mix (Black cap)
• SARS CoV2 WGS Panel B probe mix (Red cap)
• RC-PCR Probe Dilution Buffer Plus (Blue cap)
• PCR 2x Hotstart HiFi Mastermix (White cap)

Spin down:
• SARS CoV2 WGS Panel A probe mix (Black cap)
• SARS CoV2 WGS Panel B probe mix (Red cap)

Vortex for 3 seconds and spin down:
• RC-PCR Probe Dilution Buffer Plus (Blue cap)
• PCR 2x Hotstart HiFi Mastermix (White cap)
Note: The 2x mastermix contains isostabilizers and may not freeze completely, even when stored at -15°C to -25°C. The mastermix may contain precipitates when thawed at +2°C to +8°C. Always ensure that the mastermix is fully thawed and thoroughly mixed before use.

Take the two IDX PCR plates and cut off the number of strips needed from both plates. Mark the plates with “A” and “B”.
Note: Register the indexes used (IDX set / and well position for each sample). Download the index details for setting up Illumina® samplesheets at the download section of
https://www.nimagen.com/covid19

Note: For each sample, two PCR reactions are needed (pool A and pool B). Always use the same strip and well position for the same sample, in order to have identical indexes for the sample in both pools. Example: For setting up 24 samples, cut off strip 1-3 from both IDX plates and store the remaining of the plates immediately at -20°C. 2

Prepare in a fresh 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube the Probe-Polymerase premix A, by combining
• 0.2 µL panel A probe mix per reaction (black cap)
• 0.8 µL RC-PCR Probe Dilution Buffer Plus per reaction (blue cap)
• 10 µL RC-PCR 2x mastermix per reaction (white cap)
• 2 µL MBG water
Make up a mastermix for 10% extra (excess is supplied in the tubes provided). Repeat the above for panel B probe.
Quick-spin the PCR plates (A and B), and remove seals carefully.
Add to each tube of plate A: 13 µL of the Probe-Polymerase premix A.
Add to each tube of plate B: 13 µL of the Probe-Polymerase premix B.
Add to the same well position of both plate/strips A and B: 3 µL cDNA.
Close the tube strips carefully with caps (included in the kit) or plate seals and mix by vortexing 3 seconds.
Spin the plates to make sure all liquid is in the bottom of the wells.
Start the RC-PCR program in the thermal cycler(s) and place samples in the cycler when the block is between 60°C and 98°C, close the lid.

Note: While the NimaGen protocol currently specifies 2 x 0.85x SPRI bead cleanup (with beads supplied by NimaGen), improved cleanup has been achieved with 0.6x Mag-Bind® Total Pure NGS Bead cleanup (0.6x untested with NimaGen’s own SPRI beads). If Ct values are known, it is possible to alter the amount of samples in each pool for a more equal representation. As wastewater is often represented by poor Ct values, equal volume pooling is performed. However, if you have included positive controls with a Ct value significantly lower in value compared to the wastewater samples, dilution of the sample is strongly recommended to prevent excessive sequencing (use 2(wastewaterCt-positivecontrolCt)as a calculation for the dilution amount). Also, see the NimaGen handbook for further information should you wish to balance your pools more effectively (
https://www.nimagen.com/gfx/Covid19/protcol-NimaGen-covid-wgs_v201.pdf
).

Transfer 10 µl of each well of sample plate for primer panel A using an 8 channel pipette into strip tubes. You can use the same tips throughout the whole plate. Then transfer all of this to a labelled Eppendorf. Ensure the contents of the Eppendorf are mixed well by numerous inversions/shaking or brief vortexing. Pulse spin down the tube.
Repeat step 4.1 for primer panel B (and for any other plates you have).

In separate 1.5 ml tubes, pipette 240 µl of Mag-Bind® Total Pure NGS beads (or equivalent) and add 400 µl of the appropriate pool (or if required to use lower volumes, use 0.6 x of Mag-Bind Total Pure NGS beads). Mix well by numerous inversions. Leave for 5 minutes at room temperature. This should be done for each plate that has been pooled.
Pulse spin down the contents and place on a magnetic rack to pellet the beads.
Once pelleted, carefully remove the supernatant from each tube.
Add 800 µl of ethanol to each tube. Do not mix contents with the pipette, just let the ethanol sit in the tube, immersing the pelleted beads.
After waiting for 1 minute, remove the ethanol and add a further 800 µl of 80% ethanol to each tube.
Wait 1 minute. Then remove the ethanol from each tube, capping the tube after removal.
Pulse spin the tube. Place back on the magnet. After 15 seconds on the magnet, use a P20 pipette to remove any remaining ethanol from the tubes.

Remove tubes from magnetic rack and add 100 µl of LowTE (supplied in yellow tube with NimaGen kit). Flick mix tube to resuspend pellet. Allow to stand for 5 minutes at room temperature. If some of the beads appear to be stuck on the side of the tube, do another flick mix after 2 minutes.
Pulse spin down the tube and place on a magnetic rack.
Wait for at least 2 minutes for the beads to pellet and recover 100 µl of supernatant.

Add 60 µl of Mag-Bind® Total Pure NGS beads to the 100 µl of collected supernatant to perform another 0.6x bead cleanup. To do this, repeat steps 3 onwards but with adjusted volumes for beads, supernatant, 500 µl of 80% ethanol and resuspension in 25 µl of LowTE (from NimaGen kit).

Upon collection of the supernatant, measure the concentration using the Qubit HS DNA kit (or equivalent). Use 1 µl to measure the concentration but ensure accurate pipetting is performed on this low volume.
Enter the values for primer panels A and B into the NimaGen Loading Calculator for molarity calculations to assist in loading.
Optional: - Check on a fragment analyzer. You should have approximately 450 bp band with very little material below this. Higher molecular weight material is often found with wastewater samples.
Recommended loading density for sequencing the generated libraries on an Illumina NovaSeq™ 6000 is 180 pM or on an Illumina NextSeq™ is 0.9 pM, with 5% PhiX Control V3 (Illumina).

description:
This SOP describes the procedure for generating cDNA libraries from SARS-CoV-2 viral nucleic acid extracts from wastewater samples using an adaption of the Nimagen EasySeq™ SARS CoV-2 Protocol v2.01 (https://www.nimagen.com/gfx/Covid19/protcol-NimaGen-covid-wgs_v201.pdf).

The first step of this protocol is an addition to the original method, which aims to remove any PCR inhibitors from extracted RNA samples and potentially concentrate the RNA further.

During the second step, which follows the original EasySeq™ SARS CoV-2 Protocol v2.01, with some minor modifications, reverse complement PCR is performed using a panel of probes that will generate tiled amplicons covering the whole SARS-CoV-2 genome.

The final step involves an improved library clean up that will remove unused/unincorporated PCR probes, which will be more abundant in samples that contain low viral RNA concentrations.
